body: I'm ready to review again, @afchung .
Thank you all.
Could you merge this please, @anupam128 ?
I'll test and merge
Oh, I confused. Sorry, @anupam128 . And, I think I resolve conflicts that occurs now.
@dongjoon-hyun sorry I cannot merge the change as I am not a committer.

I thought you were, @anupam128 . 
You are very active, so I'm familiar with you. :-)
Thank you, @markusweimer .
During rebase, the second commit is gone. I will recover soon.
It's ready to review again.
@afchung Thanks for addressing my comments. It looks great!! I've left minor comments mainly about comments. Once you address them, I'll merge this.
It looks good to me. I'll test and merge this.
I removed the deprecated `DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation` constructor, too.

Thanks @afchung!
- For your question about `VortexFuture` constructor (I don't know why I can't see it in the UI), you're right. The constructors are used only when enqueueing to the pendingTasklets internally.
- I found that tests failed because of unused import. In the console, we can see the following messages

```
[ERROR] src\test\java\org\apache\reef\tests\applications\vortex\addone\AddOneTest.java:[25,8] (imports) UnusedImports: Unused import - org.apache.reef.vortex.api.VortexFuture.
```

This is because `VortexFunction` is imported for javadoc `{@link VortexFunction}`, but not used actually. I'll push a commit to fix it & trigger test. Once it passes, then I'll squash the commits and merge this PR.

Or not. I've tested locally and it worked. But I don't have permission to push commits on your branch. @afchung Could you please make following changes in `AddOneTest.java` and push it? Thanks!

```
-import org.apache.reef.vortex.api.VortexFuture;
```

```
-   * using {@link VortexFuture#get()}.
+   * using {@link org.apache.reef.vortex.api.VortexFuture#get()}.
```
@yunseong Sorry, didn't know that would be an issue. Removed the unused import and ran `mvn checkstyle:check` this time. Thanks!
@afchung Thanks!! I've checked the tests passed (Travis still fails, but it's irrelevant to this PR). I'll merge this.
@afchung I'll take a look.
This PR will not conflict with #675 because it does not change `VortexFunction`. @afchung Could you take a look? By the way, the callback you implemented works fine and is very useful. Thanks. :)
@afchung This looks good. Also, I tested `HelloVortex`, and found that the example crashes silently because of `null` output. Now the app finishes properly with your change. I'll merge this.
I've resolved conflicts.
This looks good. I'll test and merge.
Thank you, @afchung .
Looks good, I'll merge
Thank you, @tcNickolas .
Thank you for merging and amending commit log, @tcNickolas .
@dongjoon-hyun Why is TimeoutSubject not removed along with the test?

Because it was deprecated only in 0.14, we need to wait till after 0.14 release to remove it.

However, I would wait with removing the test until we can remove TimeoutSubject itself. Otherwise we're keeping code (which potentially has users) while removing its test coverage. I would convert this JIRA to "remove TimeoutSubject and its test" and mark it as blocked on release 0.14

To clarify: I'm -1 on merging this PR now.

Hmm, I think in another way. We can remove non-public and test codes.
Before release official 0.14 (non-incubating), I think we should clean up our code.
While test coverage metric is not observed by users, the maven build warnings on deprecated class looks very annoying.

I am fine for leaving the references in individual test projects. 

Just for your info, in general, we don't always accept auto generated project code. We created build.prop file, the main reason is to unify the way in our projects instead simply accepting default. For example, VS auto generated script which contains something like All CPU and x86, it is very easy to cause run time issue. I believe that is one of the reasons most teams create their own base level prop files to avoid confusions.
Sorry, I got a bit confused on which release we were on. In that case, I am -1 on merging as well.
Okay, no problem. Thank you, @tcNickolas and @afchung . I'll close this PR as you recommend.

Oh, @tcNickolas . Did you get the notification message? I suddenly got one. It should be like the following.

```
notifications:
  email: false
```

No, I didn't.
We probably can fix it under the same JIRA number.
Will test and merge
Sure! I reopen the issue and made a quick fix PR, #680 .
Let's wait until Jenkins build finishes, to make sure it doesn't send you notification. Then I'll merge
Yep!
I will merge this. Thanks!
This has conflicts again :-( I'll test once they are resolved

I suspect this PR will have to be updated after https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/660 is merged. JIRA mentions violations of FileMayOnlyContainASingleClass rule in Wake, but this change enables this rule while not fixing or ignoring those violations.
@afchung I assume you tested this on HDI?
I rebased. I'm happy with xUnit. :)
I'll test and merge.
Hmm. You're right. I thought I intentionally leave the rule as a false. But, it's not. After #660 , I will update this PR again.

https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-reef/builds/92784880              (REEF-1007-2, 15min ago)

@yunseong This looks good to me in general, but I would suggest usage of [`unmodifiableList`](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Collections.html#unmodifiableList%28java.util.List%29) to ensure immutability of matrices.
I'll take a look at this.
@dafrista Can you take a look at this PR as well? Given that you filed [REEF-547](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-547).

The code is updated according to the comments.
- Fix two typos
- Use '////' for comment-out code (with only code indentation)
- Exclude Avro-gen files from StyleCop check
@dongjoon-hyun Overall this looks good to me, but I don't really like the liberal use of `bindVolatileParameter`; however, I'm not really sure if there are any better solutions at the moment.

Thank you for review, @afchung .
I update the code and rebased it.
Oops, I forgot to ask review for this. @bgchun @dafrista Could you take a look? This is similar to how we've done in SNU projects.

@afchung Thanks for the review and comments! I've addressed your comments. While doing this, I've fixed some bugs in `RowMatrix` in `add()` and `multiply()`. Also, to reduce copying cost, each sub-matrix on the left side is generated at once, which was done in two steps: `generate-then-split`.
Could you take another look? Thanks a lot!

Thanks. Does callback has an API to receive an exception? 
If the client registers a callback function, it's not gonna call `get`.

@bgchun Travis tests pass in JDK 7, but failed in JDK 8. The reason was `WatcherTest`, which was reported to the [dev mailing list](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/incubator-reef-dev/201511.mbox/%3CCAFu6yH3a1FfRCxtHkCTz_p7r2xop1sYJ_yvav747MDTRDvx-pA@mail.gmail.com%3E). @gwsshs22 is looking at it.

@bgchun I didn't consider the exceptional cases: I thought the callback is optional for successful case. Client still can catch exception in `VortexFuture.get()`, but I think it would be great to send failure event via callback as well. @afchung @johnyangk  Any other thought?

We can maybe register an exception handler as well via that particular `VortexThreadPool#submit`.

This is just my opinion, but how about we do not return a `VortexFuture` from it so that there's is only one way of getting tasklet result/exception for each `VortexThreadPool#submit`?

FYI the API design in .NET threadpool:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh194741.aspx

On Wed, Nov 25, 2015 at 11:35 AM John Yang notifications@github.com wrote:

> We can maybe register an exception handler as well via that particular
> VortexThreadPool#submit.
> 
> This is just my opinion, but how about we do not return a VortexFuture
> from it so that there's is only one way of getting tasklet result/exception
> for each VortexThreadPool#submit?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/676#issuecomment-159478535
> .

Perhaps, instead of `EventHandler`, we can use [`Observer`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/blob/master/lang/java/reef-wake/wake/src/main/java/org/apache/reef/wake/rx/Observer.java) for the callback instead, and invoke `onError` on `Exceptions`. What does everyone else think?
@dafrista , could you review this?
Looks good to me. @dongjoon-hyun I'll test and merge after waiting for one more day. Thanks!
Sure, no problem. Thank you, @afchung .
Looks good, I'll merge

I don't think adding alias is a right fix for this issue. 

I am able to repro the issue on HDI cluster with master code. The root cause is in Java evaluator configuration, the configuration below was added:
 .bindImplementation(TempFileCreator.class, WorkingDirectoryTempFileCreator.class)
This is a Java implementation, not a string. And it is not used in .Net evaluator. 

A correct fix is to only set this configuration for Java evaluator. 

Currently this binding is set in EvaluatorSetupHelper, the code is common to both .Net and Java evaluator. A recommended place for the setting is at EvaluatorConfiguration and AllocatedEvaluatorImpl.makeEvaluatorConfiguration(), where you should only set it for Java only.

Sorry, I'm late to the party.

I'm not sure about these changes. The basic pattern is to create an empty Tang injector, that creates a new instance. This gets us away from using public constructors, but it doesn't remove the underlying dependencies.

The code remains brittle. For example, let's say a constructor for the DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation is added that uses a new named parameter. If the Factory class wants to use this, an extra bindVolatileParameter has to be added anyway.

It also adds one more source of brittleness. The compiler can't check if the binded instances are enough to create an instance of DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation. Using public constructors at least allows the compiler to check if the passed in instances are the correct arguments for a constructor.

That being said, I don't have a great alternative. The best I can come up with is: make the RemoteManagerImplementation constructors package-private, and un-deprecate them. This removes exposure to clients without resorting to dynamic injection.

Thoughts?
This is not meant to be a permanent fix, as I mentioned above, but rather a hotfix such that our build doesn't break anymore.
@jwang98052 Actually, I think I was able to fix it properly. Please have a look. I've rebased with the new change. Thanks!
Thank you, @tcNickolas .

Is that guideline applicable for general _Tang & Factory_ patterns?
I'm just curious because we also use `bindVolatileParameter` in `CommunicationGroupDriverFactory`.

Oh, that would be great. Could you trigger that in @dev? 
Actually, what I hope to know is _the best practice_ for using `Factory` pattern with `Tang`.

I'll merge this.

Yes. It's better to use a variation of Observer. Since Observer has a
specific contract (zero or more on Next calls followed by onCompleted or
onError), we can define a subclass of Observer like ExactlyOnceObserver
(better name?), which calls either onNext or onError. onCompleted should
raise an UnsupportedOperationException. How does this sound?

wrote:

> Perhaps, instead of EventHandler, we can use [Observer](https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/blob/master/lang/java/reef-wake/wake/src/main/java/org/apache/reef/wake/rx/Observer.java) for the callback instead, and invoke onError on Exceptions. What does
> everyone else think?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/676#issuecomment-159490376
> .

## 

Byung-Gon Chun
